# Lista 5: Modelos Lineares Generalizados (GzLM) {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false} ## Objetivo da Lista Explore **Generalized Linear Models (GzLM)** para vari√°veis resposta n√£o-normais: **regress√£o log√≠stica** (bin√°ria) e **regress√£o de Poisson** (contagem). Aprenda a interpretar Odds Ratios e Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia. ::: --- ## üì¶ Pacotes Necess√°rios ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacotes <- c( "emmeans", "tidyverse", "lme4", "nlme", "flexplot", "foreign", "dplyr", "multcomp", "effects", "sjstats", "sjPlot", "ggplot2", "forcats", "performance", "easystats", "kableExtra", "fitdistrplus", "AER", "gtsummary", "broom" ) pacotes_faltantes <- pacotes[!pacotes %in% installed.packages()[, "Package"]] if (length(pacotes_faltantes) > 0) { install.packages(pacotes_faltantes, dependencies = TRUE) } invisible(lapply(pacotes, library, character.only = TRUE)) cat("‚úì Pacotes carregados!\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ‚úì Pacotes carregados! ``` ::: ::: --- ## üì• Prepara√ß√£o dos Dados ::: {.callout-important} ## Download Necess√°rio Baixe o banco **"[Dados Amostra](https://drive.google.com/file/d/XXXXX)"** e salve na pasta do projeto. ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Carregar dados originais original <- read.spss("Dados Amostra.sav", to.data.frame = TRUE) # Criar c√≥pia de trabalho (boa pr√°tica!) db <- original ``` ::: --- ### Corre√ß√£o de Tipos ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Verificar estrutura glimpse(db) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 1,500 Columns: 10 $ id 188, 730, 855, 866, 1165, 1225, 1294, 1339, 1343, 168, 1390,‚Ä¶ $ childs 2, 2, 0, 0, 3, 2, 3, NA, NA, 0, 2, 1, 0, 0, 0, 2, 0, 1, 4, 3‚Ä¶ $ age 76, 48, 19, 38, 54, 53, 65, 52, 72, 82, 55, 43, 44, 43, 45, ‚Ä¶ $ educ 14, 12, 13, 16, 16, NA, 12, 12, 9, 15, 12, 11, 16, 16, 15, 1‚Ä¶ $ sex Female, Female, Male, Female, Female, Female, Male, Female, ‚Ä¶ $ life Routine, Routine, Exciting, Exciting, NA, Dull, NA, NA, NA, ‚Ä¶ $ tvhours 5, 1, 1, NA, 3, 4, 1, NA, NA, 2, 2, 4, 5, 2, 4, 4, 4, 3, 6, ‚Ä¶ $ attsprts NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, No, No, No, No, ‚Ä¶ $ tempo_obs 123.0000, 424.0000, 124.0000, 500.0000, 500.0000, 500.0000, ‚Ä¶ $ aderencia SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Converter vari√°veis num√©ricas db$childs <- as.integer(db$childs) db$age <- as.numeric(db$age) db$educ <- as.numeric(db$educ) db$tvhours <- as.numeric(db$tvhours) # Confirmar mudan√ßas glimpse(db) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 1,500 Columns: 10 $ id 188, 730, 855, 866, 1165, 1225, 1294, 1339, 1343, 168, 1390,‚Ä¶ $ childs 3, 3, 1, 1, 4, 3, 4, NA, NA, 1, 3, 2, 1, 1, 1, 3, 1, 2, 5, 4‚Ä¶ $ age 59, 31, 2, 21, 37, 36, 48, 35, 55, 65, 38, 26, 27, 26, 28, 6‚Ä¶ $ educ 13, 11, 12, 15, 15, NA, 11, 11, 8, 14, 11, 10, 15, 15, 14, 1‚Ä¶ $ sex Female, Female, Male, Female, Female, Female, Male, Female, ‚Ä¶ $ life Routine, Routine, Exciting, Exciting, NA, Dull, NA, NA, NA, ‚Ä¶ $ tvhours 6, 2, 2, NA, 4, 5, 2, NA, NA, 3, 3, 5, 6, 3, 5, 5, 5, 4, 7, ‚Ä¶ $ attsprts NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, No, No, No, No, ‚Ä¶ $ tempo_obs 123.0000, 424.0000, 124.0000, 500.0000, 500.0000, 500.0000, ‚Ä¶ $ aderencia SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, SIM, ‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-tip} ## üí° Boa Pr√°tica Mantenha sempre uma c√≥pia do banco original! Facilita compara√ß√µes e evita perda de dados. ::: --- ### Verificar Representatividade ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Tabelas de conting√™ncia xtabs(~ attsprts + sex, data = db) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` sex attsprts Male Female Yes 384 407 No 254 444 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} xtabs(~ attsprts + life, data = db) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` life attsprts Dull Routine Exciting Yes 16 226 281 No 48 230 190 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} xtabs(~ attsprts + aderencia, data = db) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` aderencia attsprts N√£o SIM Yes 750 41 No 0 698 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} Verifique se h√° c√©lulas vazias ou com poucos casos. Isso pode afetar a estabilidade dos modelos. ::: --- ## üéØ Parte A: Regress√£o Log√≠stica ::: {.callout-tip} ## Quando Usar? **Regress√£o Log√≠stica** √© adequada para: - **VD bin√°ria:** Sim/N√£o, Sucesso/Fracasso - Modelar probabilidade de pertencer a uma categoria - Estimar **Odds Ratios** (raz√£o de chances) **Exemplo:** Praticar esportes (Sim vs N√£o) ::: --- ### Pergunta de Pesquisa ::: {.callout-note} ## Exerc√≠cio A Qual o efeito de **sexo, opini√£o sobre vida, n√∫mero de filhos, idade, escolaridade e horas de TV** sobre a **pr√°tica de esportes**? ::: --- ### Prepara√ß√£o: N√≠veis de Refer√™ncia ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Verificar n√≠veis atuais cat("N√≠veis originais:\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` N√≠veis originais: ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print(levels(db$attsprts)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Yes" "No" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print(levels(db$sex)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Male" "Female" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print(levels(db$life)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Dull" "Routine" "Exciting" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Ajustar refer√™ncia para "No" (n√£o pratica) db$attsprts <- relevel(db$attsprts, ref = "No") cat("\nNovo n√≠vel de refer√™ncia:\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Novo n√≠vel de refer√™ncia: ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print(levels(db$attsprts)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "No" "Yes" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-important} ## Por que isso importa? Com "No" como refer√™ncia, OR > 1 indica **maior chance de praticar esportes**. ::: --- ### Ajuste do Modelo ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} modelo_logistico <- glm( attsprts ~ sex + life + childs + educ + tvhours + age, data = db, family = "binomial" ) ``` ::: ::: {.callout-note collapse="true"} ## üîç Anatomia do Modelo Log√≠stico **Fun√ß√£o:** `glm()` (Generalized Linear Model) **Family:** `binomial` com link logit (padr√£o) $$ \log\left(\frac{p}{1-p}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \ldots $$ **Interpreta√ß√£o:** - Coeficientes: mudan√ßa no log-odds - exp(coeficiente): Odds Ratio (OR) ::: --- ### Resultados: Sa√≠da B√°sica ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(modelo_logistico) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = attsprts ~ sex + life + childs + educ + tvhours + age, family = "binomial", data = db) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -1.625849 0.560416 -2.901 0.00372 ** sexFemale -0.452288 0.145961 -3.099 0.00194 ** lifeRoutine 0.649746 0.333770 1.947 0.05157 . lifeExciting 0.787760 0.336597 2.340 0.01926 * childs 0.121782 0.049603 2.455 0.01408 * educ 0.200783 0.029138 6.891 5.55e-12 *** tvhours -0.097926 0.039787 -2.461 0.01384 * age -0.036856 0.004969 -7.417 1.20e-13 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 1352.4 on 977 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 1143.6 on 970 degrees of freedom (522 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 1159.6 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-warning} Coeficientes est√£o em **log-odds**. Precisamos exponenciar para obter ORs interpret√°veis! ::: --- ### Resultados: Tabela Formatada ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tab_model( modelo_logistico, show.se = TRUE, show.aic = TRUE, show.loglik = TRUE, show.ci = TRUE, transform = "exp", title = "Regress√£o Log√≠stica: Pr√°tica de Esportes" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Regress√£o Log√≠stica: Pr√°tica de Esportes
  attsprts
Predictors Odds Ratios std. Error CI p
(Intercept) 0.20 0.11 0.00 – Inf 0.004
sex [Female] 0.64 0.09 0.00 – Inf 0.002
life [Routine] 1.92 0.64 0.00 – Inf 0.052
life [Exciting] 2.20 0.74 0.00 – Inf 0.019
childs 1.13 0.06 0.00 – Inf 0.014
educ 1.22 0.04 0.00 – Inf <0.001
tvhours 0.91 0.04 0.00 – Inf 0.014
age 0.96 0.00 0.00 – Inf <0.001
Observations 978
R2 Tjur 0.194
AIC 1159.552
log-Likelihood -571.776
````` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-tip} ## üìä Interpretando Odds Ratios **OR = 1:** Nenhum efeito **OR > 1:** Aumenta chance de praticar esportes **OR < 1:** Diminui chance de praticar esportes **Exemplo:** OR = 1.50 ‚Üí 50% mais chance ::: --- ### Resultados: Fun√ß√£o `summary()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(modelo_logistico) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = attsprts ~ sex + life + childs + educ + tvhours + age, family = "binomial", data = db) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -1.625849 0.560416 -2.901 0.00372 ** sexFemale -0.452288 0.145961 -3.099 0.00194 ** lifeRoutine 0.649746 0.333770 1.947 0.05157 . lifeExciting 0.787760 0.336597 2.340 0.01926 * childs 0.121782 0.049603 2.455 0.01408 * educ 0.200783 0.029138 6.891 5.55e-12 *** tvhours -0.097926 0.039787 -2.461 0.01384 * age -0.036856 0.004969 -7.417 1.20e-13 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 1352.4 on 977 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 1143.6 on 970 degrees of freedom (522 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 1159.6 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note collapse="true"} ## üîç Interpretando a Tabela **Colunas importantes:** - **OR:** Odds Ratio direta - **inverse.OR:** OR com refer√™ncia invertida - **p.value:** Signific√¢ncia estat√≠stica **Uso do inverse.OR:** Quando OR < 1, use inverse.OR para facilitar interpreta√ß√£o. **Exemplo com sexo:** - OR = 0.636 (Female vs Male) - inverse.OR = 1.57 (Male vs Female) **Interpreta√ß√£o (usando inverse.OR):** "Mulheres t√™m 1.57√ó mais chance de praticar esportes que homens" ::: --- ### Mudando Refer√™ncia: Demonstra√ß√£o ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Mudar refer√™ncia de sexo db$sex <- relevel(db$sex, ref = "Female") # Re-ajustar modelo modelo_logistico_v2 <- glm( attsprts ~ sex + life + childs + educ + tvhours + age, data = db, family = "binomial" ) summary(modelo_logistico_v2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = attsprts ~ sex + life + childs + educ + tvhours + age, family = "binomial", data = db) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) -2.078137 0.564641 -3.680 0.000233 *** sexMale 0.452288 0.145961 3.099 0.001944 ** lifeRoutine 0.649746 0.333770 1.947 0.051572 . lifeExciting 0.787760 0.336597 2.340 0.019265 * childs 0.121782 0.049603 2.455 0.014082 * educ 0.200783 0.029138 6.891 5.55e-12 *** tvhours -0.097926 0.039787 -2.461 0.013844 * age -0.036856 0.004969 -7.417 1.20e-13 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 1352.4 on 977 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 1143.6 on 970 degrees of freedom (522 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 1159.6 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} Note que OR do Modelo 2 = inverse.OR do Modelo 1! A escolha da refer√™ncia afeta apenas a **dire√ß√£o** da compara√ß√£o, n√£o o resultado estat√≠stico. ::: --- ## üéØ Parte D: Regress√£o de Poisson ::: {.callout-tip} ## Quando Usar? **Regress√£o de Poisson** √© adequada para: - **VD de contagem:** 0, 1, 2, 3, ... - Eventos raros - Estimar **Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia** (RP) ou Taxas **Exemplo:** N√∫mero de filhos ::: --- ### Pergunta de Pesquisa ::: {.callout-note} ## Exerc√≠cio D Qual o efeito de **sexo, opini√£o sobre vida e pr√°tica de esportes** sobre **n√∫mero de filhos**, controlando por **idade e escolaridade**? ::: --- ### Modelo 1: GLM Normal (Baseline) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} modelo_glm_normal <- glm( childs ~ sex + life + attsprts + age + educ, data = db, family = "gaussian" # Assume normalidade ) summary(modelo_glm_normal) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = childs ~ sex + life + attsprts + age + educ, family = "gaussian", data = db) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 2.872623 0.292672 9.815 < 2e-16 *** sexMale -0.186317 0.098990 -1.882 0.0601 . lifeRoutine -0.346761 0.206683 -1.678 0.0937 . lifeExciting -0.209890 0.210422 -0.997 0.3188 attsprtsYes 0.258686 0.107586 2.404 0.0164 * age 0.038723 0.002994 12.934 < 2e-16 *** educ -0.082284 0.017801 -4.623 4.3e-06 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for gaussian family taken to be 2.322978) Null deviance: 2839.0 on 983 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 2269.5 on 977 degrees of freedom (516 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 3630.8 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 2 ``` ::: ::: --- ### Modelo 2: GLM Poisson ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} modelo_poisson <- glm( childs ~ sex + life + attsprts + age + educ, data = db, family = "poisson" ) summary(modelo_poisson) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = childs ~ sex + life + attsprts + age + educ, family = "poisson", data = db) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) 0.988656 0.110271 8.966 < 2e-16 *** sexMale -0.067072 0.039024 -1.719 0.0857 . lifeRoutine -0.102725 0.074303 -1.383 0.1668 lifeExciting -0.052165 0.075989 -0.686 0.4924 attsprtsYes 0.095588 0.042782 2.234 0.0255 * age 0.013111 0.001144 11.462 < 2e-16 *** educ -0.026711 0.006805 -3.925 8.67e-05 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 951.59 on 983 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 757.85 on 977 degrees of freedom (516 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 3498.8 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 ``` ::: ::: --- ### Compara√ß√£o de Modelos ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Crit√©rios de informa√ß√£o criterios <- data.frame( Modelo = c("Normal", "Poisson"), AIC = c(AIC(modelo_glm_normal), AIC(modelo_poisson)), BIC = c(BIC(modelo_glm_normal), BIC(modelo_poisson)) ) criterios$AIC <- round(criterios$AIC, 2) criterios$BIC <- round(criterios$BIC, 2) # Marcar melhor criterios$AIC <- ifelse( criterios$AIC == min(criterios$AIC), paste0(criterios$AIC, " ‚òÖ"), criterios$AIC ) criterios$BIC <- ifelse( criterios$BIC == min(criterios$BIC), paste0(criterios$BIC, " ‚òÖ"), criterios$BIC ) knitr::kable(criterios, caption = "Compara√ß√£o: Normal vs Poisson") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Table: Compara√ß√£o: Normal vs Poisson |Modelo |AIC |BIC | |:-------|:---------|:---------| |Normal |3630.81 |3669.94 | |Poisson |3498.78 ‚òÖ |3533.02 ‚òÖ | ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} ## üìä Resultado Modelo Poisson apresenta **melhor ajuste** (menor AIC/BIC). ::: --- ### Interpreta√ß√£o: Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Usando estimates() est_poisson <- summary(modelo_poisson) print(est_poisson) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = childs ~ sex + life + attsprts + age + educ, family = "poisson", data = db) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) 0.988656 0.110271 8.966 < 2e-16 *** sexMale -0.067072 0.039024 -1.719 0.0857 . lifeRoutine -0.102725 0.074303 -1.383 0.1668 lifeExciting -0.052165 0.075989 -0.686 0.4924 attsprtsYes 0.095588 0.042782 2.234 0.0255 * age 0.013111 0.001144 11.462 < 2e-16 *** educ -0.026711 0.006805 -3.925 8.67e-05 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 951.59 on 983 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 757.85 on 977 degrees of freedom (516 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 3498.8 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-tip} ## üìä Interpretando Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia **multiplicative.coef** = exp(Œ≤) = Raz√£o de Preval√™ncia (RP) **RP = 1:** Nenhum efeito **RP > 1:** Aumenta contagem esperada **RP < 1:** Diminui contagem esperada **Exemplo:** - RP = 1.10 ‚Üí 10% mais filhos esperados - RP = 0.97 ‚Üí 3% menos filhos esperados ::: --- ### Exemplo de Interpreta√ß√£o ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Extrair coeficientes exponenciados rp_table <- data.frame( Variavel = names(coef(modelo_poisson)), RP = round(exp(coef(modelo_poisson)), 3), RP_Inversa = round(exp(-coef(modelo_poisson)), 3) ) knitr::kable( rp_table[c("attsprtsYes", "educ"), ], caption = "Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia Selecionadas" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Table: Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia Selecionadas | |Variavel | RP| RP_Inversa| |:-----------|:-----------|-----:|----------:| |attsprtsYes |attsprtsYes | 1.100| 0.909| |educ |educ | 0.974| 1.027| ::: ::: **Interpreta√ß√µes:** **Pr√°tica de Esportes (attsprtsYes):** "Pessoas que praticam esportes t√™m 10% mais chance de ter um filho adicional comparado a sedent√°rios" **Educa√ß√£o (educ):** "Para cada ano adicional de educa√ß√£o, a chance de ter um filho diminui ~3%" --- ## üîß Diagn√≥sticos e Pressupostos ### Sobredispers√£o em Poisson ::: {.callout-warning} ## ‚ö†Ô∏è Sobredispers√£o **Problema:** Vari√¢ncia > M√©dia (viola pressuposto de Poisson) **Consequ√™ncia:** Erros-padr√£o subestimados, p-valores muito otimistas **Solu√ß√£o:** Usar **Binomial Negativa** ou corre√ß√£o quasi-Poisson ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Teste formal de sobredispers√£o dispersiontest(modelo_poisson, trafo = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Overdispersion test data: modelo_poisson z = -5.1887, p-value = 1 alternative hypothesis: true alpha is greater than 0 sample estimates: alpha -0.2078915 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} ## Interpreta√ß√£o **H‚ÇÄ:** N√£o h√° sobredispers√£o **p < 0.05:** Sobredispers√£o detectada ‚Üí Considerar Binomial Negativa ::: --- ### Gr√°ficos Diagn√≥sticos ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} par(mfrow = c(2, 3)) plot(modelo_poisson, which = 1:6) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lista_5_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=1152} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) ``` ::: --- ## üîß Extras Avan√ßados ### Pseudo R¬≤ ::: {.callout-tip} ## O que √© Pseudo R¬≤? An√°logo ao R¬≤ para modelos log√≠sticos/Poisson. Indica "propor√ß√£o de verossimilhan√ßa explicada". **M√©todos comuns:** - **Hosmer-Lemeshow:** Baseado em deviance - **Cox-Snell:** Ajustado pelo tamanho amostral - **Nagelkerke:** Normalizado para variar 0-1 ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Fun√ß√£o personalizada logisticPseudoR2s <- function(LogModel) { dev <- LogModel$deviance nullDev <- LogModel$null.deviance modelN <- length(LogModel$fitted.values) R.l <- 1 - dev / nullDev R.cs <- 1 - exp(-(nullDev - dev) / modelN) R.n <- R.cs / (1 - (exp(-(nullDev / modelN)))) data.frame( Metodo = c("Hosmer-Lemeshow", "Cox-Snell", "Nagelkerke"), Pseudo_R2 = c(round(R.l, 3), round(R.cs, 3), round(R.n, 3)) ) } # Aplicar ao modelo log√≠stico logisticPseudoR2s(modelo_logistico) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Metodo Pseudo_R2 1 Hosmer-Lemeshow 0.154 2 Cox-Snell 0.192 3 Nagelkerke 0.257 ``` ::: ::: --- ### Corre√ß√£o de Bonferroni ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Quando Usar Corre√ß√µes? **Problema:** M√∫ltiplas compara√ß√µes inflam erro Tipo I **Corre√ß√µes dispon√≠veis:** - **Bonferroni:** Mais conservadora (divide Œ± por n¬∫ de testes) - **Holm:** Menos conservadora, sequencial - **Hochberg:** Similar a Holm - **FDR (Benjamini-Hochberg):** Controla taxa de falsas descobertas **Trade-off:** Prote√ß√£o contra falsos positivos ‚Üî Poder estat√≠stico ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tab_model( modelo_logistico, show.se = TRUE, show.ci = TRUE, transform = "exp", p.adjust = "bonferroni", title = "Regress√£o Log√≠stica com Corre√ß√£o de Bonferroni" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

Qual combina√ß√£o explica melhor os dados? ::: --- ## üìö Material Complementar ### Aula em V√≠deo (SPSS) {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IHhhsXYZ-1A title='GLzM - Generalized Linear Model - Aula Pr√°tica #5 (SPSS)' >}} --- ### Recursos Adicionais ::: {.callout-note collapse="true"} ## üìñ Leituras Recomendadas **Regress√£o Log√≠stica:** - Hosmer & Lemeshow (2013). *Applied Logistic Regression* - [UCLA Stats Guide - Logistic Regression](https://stats.oarc.ucla.edu/r/dae/logit-regression/) **Regress√£o de Poisson:** - [Bookdown: Poisson Regression](https://bookdown.org/drki_musa/dataanalysis/poisson-regression.html) - Agresti (2015). *Foundations of Linear and Generalized Linear Models* **V√≠deos:** - [StatQuest: Logistic Regression](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QPY4zuxs1W0) ::: --- ### Decis√£o: Poisson vs Binomial Negativa ::: {.callout-tip} ## Guia R√°pido | Situa√ß√£o | Modelo Recomendado | |----------|-------------------| | Vari√¢ncia ‚âà M√©dia | Poisson | | Vari√¢ncia >> M√©dia | Binomial Negativa | | Muitos zeros | Zero-Inflated Poisson/NB | | Eventos raros | Poisson | **Testar sobredispers√£o:** Use `dispersiontest()` ou compare AIC de Poisson vs NB ::: --- ## üîß Informa√ß√µes de Sess√£o ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} report(sessionInfo()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Analyses were conducted using the R Statistical language (version 4.4.2; R package version 1.4.0, . ``` ::: ::: --- ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple"} ## üéì Resumo da Lista 5 Nesta lista voc√™: ‚úÖ Dominou **regress√£o log√≠stica** para vari√°veis bin√°rias ‚úÖ Aprendeu a interpretar **Odds Ratios** ‚úÖ Explorou **regress√£o de Poisson** para contagens ‚úÖ Calculou e interpretou **Raz√µes de Preval√™ncia** ‚úÖ Comparou modelos via **AIC/BIC** ‚úÖ Testou **sobredispers√£o** em Poisson ‚úÖ Aplicou **corre√ß√µes para compara√ß√µes m√∫ltiplas** **Conceitos-chave:** - GzLM estende GLM para distribui√ß√µes n√£o-normais - Log√≠stica: OR interpreta mudan√ßas em chances - Poisson: RP interpreta mudan√ßas em contagens - Sobredispers√£o: problema comum que requer aten√ß√£o **Pr√≥ximos passos:** - Explore intera√ß√µes complexas - Teste modelos Zero-Inflated para excesso de zeros - Pratique interpreta√ß√£o de ORs e RPs - Compare com Binomial Negativa quando apropriado :::
